Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies the mathematical theory of dynamical systems with multiple time scales and develops new computational methods for bringing this theory to bear upon models of biological phenomena. The research employs geometric approaches to study these problems. In particular, it investigates invariant manifolds that play a key role in organizing complex oscillations. New computational methods for computing these manifolds are one focus of the research. Indeed, there is a general lack of methods for computer investigation of manifolds. Creation of a comprehensive ``smooth computational geometry'' is a long term goal of the research. The project also seeks to develop methods for fitting models to data. It is rare that all of the parameters of a complex dynamical model can be measured or that systematic methods are used to estimate these parameters from empirical time series data. With multiple time scale systems, this is a particularly difficult optimization problem because abrupt changes in the dynamics are not readily fit by the quadratic models upon which smooth optimization algorithms are based. This project seeks to identify where these abrupt changes occur. The methods also enable accurate sensitivity analysis that describes the rates of change of model trajectories as parameters are varied. They are designed to contribute to the toolkit of methods available for designing engineered systems with periodic operating states rather than ones which are steady.

Dynamical systems theory is astonishingly successful in relating widely disparate phenomena observed in population dynamics, chemical reactions, lasers and much more. This project follows this tradition, seeking to explain universal dynamical behaviors observed in rhythmic processes, many of which display complex oscillations. Respiration, the heartbeat, circadian rhythms, menstrual cycles and animal locomotion are a few examples of biological rhythms to which the methods apply. All the primary modes of locomotion of higher animals: walking, running, slithering, swimming and flying result from cyclic motions of the body. Bursting oscillations that are ubiquitous in the nervous system exemplify temporal complexity: epochs of active firing of neurons alternate with quiescent periods. In mixed mode oscillations of non-equilibrium chemical reactors, epochs of large and small amplitude oscillations alternate. Multiple time scales are inherent in these complex oscillations. Thus, this project develops new methods for the analysis of dynamical systems with multiple time scales and the results yield a deeper mathematical understanding of how rapid changes in a system can result from variations of slow components. Geometric models reduce the mechanisms for such changes to their simplest forms and provide mathematical explanations for enigmatic results obtained from numerical simulations of systems with multiple time scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ordinary differential equations are common models of planetary motion, electrical circuits, chemical reactions, mechanical linkages, interacting populations and much more. Dynamical systems theory discovers geometric patterns that organize the solutions to such equations. A major achievement of the theory has been the classification of generic bifurcations that characterize how solutions change when system parameters are varied. Bifurcation theory leads to numerical methods that map parameter spaces into regions with qualitatively similar behavior. This project has contributed to extending this theory to systems with multiple time scales.


Neuroscience serves as an application area to explain the results. Action potentials are fast spikes of electrical current across nerve membranes that propagate information in the nervous system. Bursting (alternation of groups of action potentials with quiescent activity) and mixed mode oscillations (alternation of groups of action potentials with subthreshold oscillations) are two important phenomena that underlie behaviors like locomotion. Differential equations with multiple time scales model this electrical activity and are compared with experimental data that show the system response to external stimuli, effects of neuromodulators, etc. Mapping the parameter spaces of these models into regions where neurons and networks are quiescent, fire action potentials periodically, burst or have more complicated behaviors is a continuing challenge. 


This project developed mathematics that helps compute parameter space maps and organize the resulting information. It classified different ways in which multiple time scales lead naturally to mixed mode oscillations (MMOs) and found new types of bifurcations at MMO parameter space boundaries. As often happens with mathematics, the results are general and have been found to apply in seemingly unrelated settings. MMOs were discovered and studied intensively in the 1980s in chemical reactors, but there was insufficient mathematics for a comprehensive understanding of model simulations. This project has brought new insight in this area. 


Surprisingly, this project has recently brought MMO theory to the analysis of low order models of El Nino. Strong El Nino events are episodic climate events in the tropical Pacific that affect weather globally. These events occur roughly once per decade.  Historical data indicates that their frequency is irregular, and indeed the strong El Nino of 2015-16 was preceded by predictions that it would occur a year earlier. Dynamical systems theory provides a promising setting for understanding better the predictability of El Nino events.


This project also sponsored research on reconstructing dynamical systems from data. The data came from motion capture of humans running on a treadmill. Ideal motion is represented by a periodic orbit in the phase space of body positions and velocities. The goal of the work was to use observed fluctuations around this ideal orbit to infer information about motion of the center of mass and to determine how the locomotion was controlled. The starting point was a model that reduces the runner to a point mass on top of a massless, springy leg. Control in the model is implemented by setting the direction and stiffness of the swing leg each step. Spring-mass models have long been used for human and animal running. With constant parameters fit to a human, the mass eventually falls to the ground. Thus, stability requires "active" control. The study reconstructed control laws from the data with optimization algorithms. Based upon earlier work, fits between the model and data were evaluated on two criteria:, (1) how well the position of the center of mass was predicted one step ahead and (2) how well the model reproduced eigenvalues that are a quantitative measure of stability....
